emailColumn.title: Torus: Building FinTech Bridges from Local Data Solutions to European Banking Giants

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Kirill Lisitsyn is the co-founder of Torus, a financial technology company specializing in data transparency solutions between international payment platforms and banks. With experience expanding across Europe and into Asia through strategic partnerships, he has navigated the complex world of B2B FinTech sales, regulatory compliance, and long enterprise sales cycles. His company operates in the rapidly growing European FinTech market, valued at over $380 billion and expanding at 18.5% CAGR, focusing on solving global inefficiencies in financial data exchange.

materialsUsed: Europe FinTech Market projected to reach $380.8 billion by 2032, growing at 18.5% CAGR. (2024). IMARC Group.
European FinTech market valued at $3.6 trillion in transaction value with 2,500+ companies in UK alone. (2024). Fine Network.
B2B sales cycles averaging 4+ months for financial services, with 75% taking minimum 4 months to complete. (2024). CSO Insights.
Key FinTech trends in Europe: Open banking, digital payments dominance, regulatory frameworks like MiCAR. (2024). Deutsche Bank Flow.
Average B2B conversion rates: 13% leads to opportunities in 84 days, 6% opportunities to deals in 18 days. (2024). Implisit Research.

keyTakeaways.title: Strategic Success Factors
keyTakeaways.description: This FinTech expansion story demonstrates that successful European market entry requires three essential elements: leveraging global problem uniformity (data exchange formats are the same worldwide, making solutions universally applicable), building strategic local partnerships (investors and accelerators provided crucial market access and credibility), and embracing extended B2B sales cycles (what seemed like 3-month deals actually took 12+ months). The key insight: remote operations work in FinTech when average deal sizes don't justify travel costs, and cultural differences across Europe are smaller than expected. Most importantly, always have a Plan B - B2B sales cycles are consistently longer than anticipated, and multiple channels (introductions, outreach, partnerships) are essential for sustainable growth.

emails.subject: Global Problem, Global Solution: Why We Went International from Day One
emails.body:
You asked about when we first started considering international markets, and I wanted to share our journey.

We initially hypothesized that what we were doing – solving inefficiencies in financial data transparency between international platforms like Visa and Mastercard, and banks – was addressing a global problem 🌍. After conducting several pilots and realizing there was demand, we secured our first customer and began earning revenue.

From an early stage, we recognized the need to build a large geographical international presence 📈. The data exchange format is uniform globally, which means the same problems exist worldwide. After gaining some initial traction, we started considering expansion, looking first to Europe due to its proximity and support ecosystem 🇪🇺.

The beautiful thing about our solution is that financial data standards are universal 💳. Whether you're in New York, London, or Tokyo, Visa and Mastercard transactions follow the same protocols. Banks everywhere struggle with the same transparency issues. This gave us confidence that our product-market fit would translate across borders.

We also realized early that the European FinTech market is incredibly mature and supportive 🚀. With over $380 billion in market value and growing at 18.5% annually, Europe offers the perfect ecosystem for FinTech innovation. Countries like the UK have over 2,500 FinTech companies, and the regulatory framework through initiatives like PSD2 and open banking actually encourages the kind of data transparency solutions we provide.

The timing was perfect too ⏰. As digital payments exploded globally and regulatory pressure for financial transparency increased, our solution became not just nice-to-have, but essential for banks wanting to stay competitive and compliant.

highlight.title: Universal Problem Recognition
highlight.description: They discovered something super smart: financial data works the same way everywhere in the world! It's like how math is the same whether you're in America or Japan - 2+2=4 everywhere. Since banks and credit card companies use the same systems globally, the problems they solve in one country exist in every country. This made going international much easier because they didn't need to change their product for different places.

emails.subject: Why Europe Over America: Following the Network Effect
emails.body:
You asked why we chose Europe instead of America for our initial expansion.

Our decision was influenced by several factors 🤔. We had industry contacts in Latvia, which provided us with a network there and introduced us to startup programs and opportunities in the region.

We applied for and were accepted into a startup program in Latvia, establishing our first European company there 🇱🇻. Later, we found investors from Lithuania, 70 Ventures, who required us to form a company in their country as a condition for investment 💰. We successfully secured funding and established our Lithuanian business entity.

We didn't conduct extensive market research – our approach was more about testing and learning 🧪. The product was built to serve customers from different countries easily. The data format is the same globally, and we work only with anonymous data, so there weren't significant regulatory barriers.

What really attracted us to Europe was the incredible FinTech infrastructure that's already in place 🏗️. The European market processes over $3.6 trillion in transaction value annually, and countries like Germany, France, and the Netherlands have some of the most advanced digital banking ecosystems in the world.

Europe also has something America doesn't: harmonized regulations across 27 countries through the EU framework 📋. This means once you comply with European standards, you can potentially access a massive market. The regulatory environment is actually quite FinTech-friendly, especially with initiatives like MiCAR (Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation) setting clear rules that encourage innovation.

The network effect was huge for us 🕸️. Having contacts in Latvia opened doors to accelerators, which led to investors in Lithuania, which then connected us to banking partners across the region. In FinTech, relationships and trust are everything, and Europe's interconnected startup ecosystem made it easier to build those crucial partnerships.

Plus, the time zone alignment with our home market made operations much more manageable than trying to coordinate with US West Coast schedules ⏰.

highlight.title: Network-Driven Expansion
highlight.description: Instead of doing tons of research and picking markets like choosing from a menu, they followed their connections! It's like when you move to a new school and become friends with someone who introduces you to their friends, who introduce you to more friends. Their contact in Latvia led to startup programs, which led to investors in Lithuania, which opened doors across Europe. Sometimes the best strategy is following the path where people already know and trust you!

emails.subject: European Market Strategy: Accelerators, Mentors, and B2B Outreach
emails.body:
You inquired about how we approached the European market.

After establishing ourselves in Lithuania, we received support from both our investor and Startup Wise Guys accelerator program in Italy 🇮🇹. They helped us build a B2B outreach strategy, including email marketing campaigns. We started with English-speaking or English-proficient countries to facilitate communication 🗣️.

Our approach was guided by our mentors 👨‍🏫. We focused on reaching out to target companies and found that conversion rates for demos were relatively good. About 8 out of 10 prospects would ask questions like "how much does it cost?" – indicating genuine interest 💡.

The sales cycle, however, was much longer than anticipated ⏳. Selling to banks involved extended onboarding cycles. Fortunately, we had signed our first European pilot, which gave us a foothold as we pivoted fully to international markets.

What we learned about B2B FinTech sales in Europe is fascinating 📊. The average B2B sales cycle in financial services takes a minimum of 4 months, with 75% taking even longer. For banks specifically, we discovered that deals involving data integration and compliance can stretch 6-12 months because of regulatory reviews and internal approval processes.

The accelerator support was invaluable 🚀. Startup Wise Guys didn't just provide mentorship - they gave us credibility. When you're a relatively unknown FinTech trying to sell to major European banks, having accelerator backing signals that you've been vetted by industry experts. It opens doors that would otherwise remain firmly closed.

Our email outreach strategy evolved significantly 📧. We learned that European banks receive hundreds of FinTech pitches monthly, so generic outreach fails. Instead, we focused on demonstrating specific understanding of each bank's regulatory environment and current pain points. We'd reference their recent compliance reports or digital transformation announcements to show we'd done our homework.

The language strategy was crucial too 🌐. Starting with English-proficient markets (UK, Netherlands, Nordic countries) allowed us to perfect our pitch before expanding to markets requiring localization. This staged approach prevented us from spreading too thin while still moving fast.

highlight.title: Strategic Market Sequencing
highlight.description: They were super smart about which countries to approach first! Instead of trying to talk to everyone at once, they started with countries where people speak English well (like the UK and Netherlands). It's like learning to ride a bike in your driveway before trying to ride on busy streets. This let them practice their sales pitch and fix any problems before expanding to countries where they'd need to translate everything. The accelerator program was like having a famous friend introduce you - it made banks much more likely to listen to them!

emails.subject: Reality Check: When 3 Months Becomes 12 Months
emails.body:
You asked about when we realized our expectations weren't matching reality and how we handled it.

The realization was gradual 📈. We secured a partner in Italy who was introducing us to banks, and meetings were happening – but slowly. What we thought would take three months stretched to twelve ⏰.

Our original strategy from early 2022 anticipated that we'd sign a few clients with substantial checks within a year 💰. In reality, it took almost two years. External events significantly affected the market, and we had to adapt quickly.

This reality check taught us so much about B2B FinTech sales 🎓. The research shows that 13% of leads convert to opportunities over an average of 84 days, and only 6% of opportunities convert to actual deals (though that final conversion happens faster, in about 18 days). What this means in practice is that for every 100 banks we contact, maybe 13 will show serious interest, and only 1-2 will actually buy.

Banks move incredibly slowly for good reasons 🏛️. They're dealing with people's money, regulatory oversight, and complex legacy systems. A single integration decision can affect millions of transactions daily. We learned that what feels like procrastination to a startup is actually prudent risk management from their perspective.

The external events (economic uncertainty, changing regulations, bank consolidations) added another 3-6 months to cycles that were already long 🌪️. Banks become even more conservative during uncertain times, adding extra approval layers and extending evaluation periods.

We adapted by changing our entire business model approach 🔄. Instead of forecasting based on optimistic 3-month cycles, we started planning for 12-18 month averages. This meant:

- Building a much larger pipeline to account for low conversion rates 📊
- Securing longer runway funding to survive extended sales cycles 💸
- Developing interim milestone payments and pilot programs to generate cash flow 🎯
- Creating detailed nurturing sequences to keep prospects engaged over long periods 📧

The key insight: in B2B FinTech, patience isn't just a virtue - it's a survival requirement 🧘‍♂️.

highlight.title: Patience as Strategy
highlight.description: They learned that selling to banks is like growing a tree instead of picking flowers! They thought it would take 3 months to get customers, but it actually took 12 months. Banks are super careful because they handle everyone's money, so they take a really long time to make decisions. It's like when your parents take forever to choose a new car because it's expensive and important. The smart thing they did was change their plan to expect long waits, so they wouldn't run out of money while waiting for customers to decide.

emails.subject: Remote-First Success: Cultural Insights Across Europe
emails.body:
You asked about remote operations and cultural differences.

We operated almost entirely remotely 💻. Most of our client acquisition happened virtually. Our first Luxembourg client signed without ever meeting us in person 🇱🇺.

The COVID pandemic helped normalize remote business 🦠. Our average deal size doesn't justify flying for a single meeting, so this shift worked in our favor.

Culturally, we found that business practices across Europe were less different than expected 🌍. We've now expanded to Japan through a partner and are exploring opportunities in the Middle East. For more culturally distinct markets, local partnerships have been essential.

The remote-first approach turned out to be a huge advantage in FinTech 🚀. European banks were already digitizing rapidly, and COVID accelerated this transformation. Video calls became the norm, not the exception. Our Luxembourg client actually preferred virtual meetings because it allowed their technical team to join easily without travel logistics.

We discovered that European business culture is remarkably consistent when it comes to FinTech adoption 📊. Whether we're talking to a bank in Amsterdam, Milan, or Stockholm, the decision-makers speak similar languages around risk management, compliance, and digital transformation. The regulatory frameworks (PSD2, GDPR, MiCAR) create a common vocabulary across the region.

The cultural differences that do matter are subtler 🎭:
- German banks want extensive technical documentation upfront
- UK banks focus heavily on ROI calculations and business cases
- Nordic banks prioritize sustainability and ESG compliance
- Southern European banks emphasize relationship-building phases

Our deal sizes typically range from €50K to €500K annually 💰. For transactions in this range, the cost of in-person meetings (flights, hotels, time) often represents 2-5% of the total deal value. Remote closing became not just convenient, but economically sensible.

The key to remote success in FinTech: impeccable technical demos 🖥️. When you can't shake hands and build rapport over dinner, your product demonstration must be flawless. We invested heavily in creating interactive, customizable demos that prospects could explore on their own time.

highlight.title: Remote Relationship Building
highlight.description: They discovered that you don't always need to meet people face-to-face to do business! During COVID, everyone got used to video calls, and it turned out that banks actually liked it better sometimes. It's like how you can become good friends with someone online - the relationship is real even if you've never met in person. They found that European countries are more similar than different when it comes to business, kind of like how kids from different schools still love the same video games and follow similar rules.

emails.subject: Lead Generation Evolution: From Introductions to Systematic Outreach
emails.body:
You asked about lead generation strategies.

We started with introductions – "someone knows someone" 🤝. Later, we added email marketing to broaden reach. We experimented with LinkedIn outreach and conferences, and now have a dedicated CMO to streamline efforts.

Europe's vacation patterns taught us to avoid outreach in August and December 🏖️. Business development is most productive in February-April and September–November.

One of our most promising channels is partnership-based selling 🤝. For example, our Japanese client came through a local processor introduced by our mentor at the Alchemist Accelerator.

The evolution of our lead generation reflects the maturation of European FinTech markets 📈. In the early days, warm introductions were everything - the market was smaller, and everyone knew everyone. But as the sector exploded (Europe now has 2,500+ FinTech companies just in the UK), we needed more systematic approaches.

Our LinkedIn strategy became quite sophisticated 💼. We discovered that European banking executives are very active on LinkedIn, but they're also bombarded with FinTech pitches. Our breakthrough came when we started sharing genuine insights about regulatory changes and industry trends, rather than just promoting our product. This positioned us as thought leaders first, vendors second.

Conference networking transformed post-COVID 🎤. Virtual events initially felt less valuable, but they actually democratized access. We could "attend" 5-10 European FinTech conferences monthly without travel costs. The key was being selective - focusing on compliance-focused events where our data transparency message resonated most.

The seasonal patterns were eye-opening 📅:
- August: Europe essentially shuts down. Don't bother.
- December: Holiday wind-down starts mid-month
- January: Slow restart, budget planning mode
- February-April: Peak decision-making season
- May-June: Good, but competing with summer planning
- September-November: Second peak as Q4 budget spending accelerates

Partnership channels became our secret weapon 🎯. Instead of trying to reach every bank directly, we partnered with payment processors, compliance consultants, and systems integrators who already had established relationships. They provide the credibility and trust that opens doors, while we provide the technical solution that solves real problems.

highlight.title: Multi-Channel Evolution
highlight.description: They learned that finding customers is like fishing - you need different techniques for different situations! They started by asking friends to introduce them to potential customers (like having your friend introduce you to their cool older sibling). Then they learned to use LinkedIn like a professional networking playground, and discovered that going to industry conferences (even virtual ones) was like attending clubs where everyone shares the same interests. The smartest discovery: partnering with other companies who already know the customers you want to meet!

emails.subject: Team Structure and Scaling: English-First, Localize Later
emails.body:
You asked about team structure and language.

We document everything in English and are preparing to scale further 📚. As we expand into new regions, we'll add local language capabilities where needed. We've worked with team members from the Netherlands and Portugal, and we're optimistic about a more diverse team structure 🌍.

Our English-first approach proved strategic for several reasons 🎯. FinTech is inherently global, and English serves as the lingua franca for financial services technology. European banks, especially those with international operations, expect FinTech vendors to communicate in English at the technical level.

The talent pool advantages are significant 👥. By maintaining English documentation and processes, we can hire the best FinTech talent from across Europe without geographical constraints. Our Portuguese developer brings expertise in EU banking regulations, while our Dutch team member has deep knowledge of PSD2 implementation.

We're seeing interesting patterns in language requirements by market segment 🗺️:
- Tier 1 banks (major internationals): English-only is often preferred
- Tier 2 banks (regional players): English acceptable, local language nice-to-have
- Tier 3 banks (local/community): Local language often essential

Our scaling strategy addresses this pragmatically 📊. For technical documentation, API guides, and product specifications, English remains our standard. For sales materials, case studies, and customer success content, we're building localized versions for key markets.

The regulatory compliance aspect is crucial 📋. European financial regulations are published in multiple languages, but the technical implementation standards are typically English-first. Our ability to navigate MiCAR, PSD2, and GDPR documentation in English gives us faster market entry capabilities.

Team composition is becoming more strategic 🎪:
- Core product team: English-fluent, European time zones
- Sales team: Bilingual capabilities for key markets
- Customer success: Local language speakers for Tier 3 banks
- Compliance team: Native speakers familiar with local regulatory nuances

The beauty of European FinTech talent is the natural multilingual capabilities 🌟. Most of our European hires speak 2-3 languages fluently, giving us flexibility to serve multiple markets without dedicated localization for each country.

highlight.title: Strategic Language Planning
highlight.description: They made a smart choice to start with English for everything, kind of like how kids learn basic math before advanced calculus! Since most big banks in Europe can work in English, they didn't need to translate everything right away. But they're planning ahead - as they grow, they'll add people who speak local languages for smaller banks that prefer their own language. It's like having a friend who can translate when you visit their grandparents who don't speak English!

emails.subject: Partner Motivation: Beyond Revenue Sharing
emails.body:
You asked about partner motivation.

We learned that revenue-share alone isn't enough 💰. Partners often lose interest when deals take longer than expected. We've seen better engagement when our solution complements their offerings or solves their clients' problems 🎯.

We sometimes pay for qualified demo calls to recognize a partner's time investment 💡. Non-financial incentives like regular calls and conference invitations also help. Weekly check-ins keep partnerships active and aligned 📞.

The psychology of B2B FinTech partnerships is fascinating 🧠. When we first started, we assumed partners would be motivated primarily by commission potential. But we discovered that European FinTech partners - whether they're systems integrators, consultants, or complementary vendors - are actually more motivated by strategic value alignment.

Successful partnerships happen when our data transparency solution makes their core offering more valuable 🚀. For example, when a compliance consultant can demonstrate that they've helped a bank implement better data visibility (using our platform), it strengthens their own client relationship and justifies their fees.

The timing mismatch problem is real ⏰. European partners typically expect FinTech deals to close in 6-9 months (which is already long by other industry standards), but our bank deals often take 12-18 months. Partners start questioning their time investment when month 10 arrives with no closed deal.

Our evolved partner motivation strategy includes 🎯:
- Qualified demo call payments (€200-500 per genuine prospect meeting)
- Joint marketing opportunities (co-branded whitepapers, webinar partnerships)
- Early access to new features for their own evaluation
- Annual partner conference invitations (networking value often exceeds monetary incentives)
- Technical certification programs that enhance their credibility

Weekly check-ins aren't just about deal updates 📊. We use these calls to:
- Share market intelligence about regulatory changes
- Discuss other partners' success stories (with appropriate anonymization)
- Provide product roadmap previews
- Gather feedback on market needs they're seeing

The best partners become genuine advocates 🏆. They start mentioning our solution unprompted in client conversations because they genuinely believe it adds value to their service delivery. This authentic advocacy is worth far more than any commission structure.

highlight.title: Partnership Psychology
highlight.description: They discovered that business partners are like teammates in a sport - they need more than just money to stay motivated! Partners get excited when working together makes them both look good to their customers. It's like when you and your friend both get credit for a group project. They learned to keep partners engaged by sharing cool information, inviting them to special events, and checking in regularly - just like maintaining any good friendship, but for business!

emails.subject: Hard-Won Lessons: Always Have a Plan B
emails.body:
You asked about lessons learned.

A key lesson: always have a Plan B 🎯. Timeframes are often longer than expected. For example, we paid a retainer to Italian partners – in hindsight, performance-based would've been better. But they did connect us with a major bank 🏛️.

We learned to combine multiple channels: introductions, outreach, conferences 📊. Also, competitors can become collaborators – consultants use our platform to automate analysis they previously did manually 🤝.

The best partnerships align beyond money 💡. Regular engagement is critical. Weekly calls with a partner keep momentum high – a lesson we're working to apply across the board.

Our biggest lesson about European B2B FinTech expansion: everything takes 2-3x longer than you think, but the relationships you build are incredibly valuable 📈. The European banking sector moves slowly but rewards patience with substantial, long-term contracts.

The Plan B principle became essential 🎪. When our primary Italian partnership showed slower results than expected, we had already started building relationships with accelerators in other countries. This parallel approach meant we weren't dependent on any single market entry strategy.

Channel diversification saved us multiple times 🌊:
- When email outreach hit spam filters, we had LinkedIn relationships
- When conference networking went virtual, we had partner introductions
- When one accelerator program ended, we had developed direct bank relationships
- When regulatory changes slowed one market, we could pivot to others

The competitor-to-collaborator insight was unexpected 🔄. We initially saw other FinTech companies as threats, but discovered that the European market is large enough for specialization. Compliance consultants started licensing our data analysis capabilities rather than building competing solutions. This B2B2B model actually scaled faster than direct sales.

Retainer vs. performance-based partnerships taught us about risk alignment 💰. When we pay retainers, partners feel less urgency to deliver results. Performance-based models (commission on closed deals, success fees) keep everyone aligned on outcomes. The Italian partnership taught us this lesson expensively but valuably.

Regular engagement frequency matters more than call duration 📞. Thirty-minute weekly calls are more effective than two-hour monthly meetings. Momentum dies quickly in B2B FinTech - a two-week gap can mean your contact has moved on to more urgent priorities.

Most importantly: European FinTech expansion is a marathon, not a sprint 🏃‍♂️. The companies that succeed are those that build systematic, sustainable processes rather than chasing quick wins.

highlight.title: Multiple Safety Nets
highlight.description: They learned that business expansion is like learning to juggle - you need backup plans for when things go wrong! Instead of putting all their hopes on one approach, they tried many different ways to find customers at the same time. They also discovered that companies they thought were competitors could actually become friends who help each other. It's like realizing that the kid who's also good at math could be your study partner instead of just competition. The biggest lesson: stay in touch with people regularly, even if it's just quick check-ins!

emails.subject: Future Focus: Outsourcing and Systematic Growth
emails.body:
You asked about outsourcing and lead generation.

We've worked with external SDRs, marketers, and contractors 👥. We've tested outreach tools, including AI-driven ones, but found that contact list quality matters more ✨.

We send only 100–200 messages a week, so automation isn't the key 📧. Our product is specialized, and targeted outreach – e.g. to former executives in payment systems – brings better results 🎯.

We're now focusing on partner outreach and plan to formalize this strategy 🤝. The cycles are long, but we're optimistic.

Our approach.

highlight.title: Quality Beats Quantity in Outreach
highlight.description: They discovered that sending fewer, better messages works way better than sending tons of random ones! It's like the difference between writing a thoughtful birthday card to your best friend versus sending the same generic 'Happy Birthday' text to everyone you know. They only send 100-200 carefully chosen messages per week, but they make sure each one goes to exactly the right person - like former payment system executives who actually understand their product. They learned that having a really good list of the right people to contact is more important than having fancy robots send thousands of messages. It's like having a small group of really good friends who actually care about what you're doing, instead of trying to be friends with everyone in the whole school!
